facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 275 of 1969 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 275 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated November 5, 1968 of Kerala High Court in C.R.P. No. 1482 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 5, 1968 of the Kerala High Court in C.R.P. No. 1482 of 1968.

facts.text: Kerala High Court dismissed petition under s. 115 CPC from order of District Judge of Kottayam.

anchor.surface_text: K. Daphtary, Sardar Bahadur, Vishnu Bahadur and Yougindra Khushalani, for the appellant. C. Chagla and R. Gopalakrishnan, for respondents Nos. 3 and 4. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Mitter, J. This is an appeal by special leave from a judgment and decree of the Kerala High Court dismissing a petition under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure from an order of the District Judge of Kottayam.

facts.text: Appellant was monthly tenant of four houses covered by single tenancy at rent of Rs. 250 granted in 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are as follows. The appellant before us was a monthly tenant of four houses companyered by a single tenancy at a rent of Rs. 250 granted in 1953.

facts.text: Landlord filed petition in Rent Control Court of Kottayam for eviction on grounds of personal use and sub-letting.

anchor.surface_text: The landlord filed a petition in the Rent Control Court of Kottayam for eviction of the tenant on the ground that he required the premises for his personal use and occupation, and, secondly, that the tenant was guilty of sub-letting and as such number entitled to protection under the Kerala Buildings  Lease and Rent Control  Act, 1959.

facts.text: Petition for eviction filed on August 31, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The petition for eviction was filed on August 31, 1965 after the companying into force of the new Act.

facts.text: Kerala Buildings Lease and Rent Control Act, 1965 came into force on 1st April, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: It is pertinent to numbere here that the Kerala Act of 1959 was repealed by the Kerala Buildings  Lease and Rent Control  Act, 1965 and the new Act came into force on 1st April, 1965.

facts.text: Rent Controller held against landlord on both eviction grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The Controller held against the landlord on both the points.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held no sub-letting but landlord required premises for personal use; allowed eviction from two out of four properties as they had separate agreements.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal being preferred therefrom, the Subordinate Judge held that there was numbersub- letting by the tenant but the landlord required the premises for his personal use and occupation. He however found that two of the buildings formed the subject matter of separate and independent agreements between the parties and as such allowed eviction of the tenants from two only out of the four properties.

facts.text: District Judge held landlord did not prove bona fide requirement for personal use but there was sub-letting; ordered eviction from all four buildings.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge held that the landlord had number proved that he bona fide required the premises let for his personal use and occupation but disagreeing with the Subordinate Judge he held that there had been in fact sub-letting and on the basis thereof ordered eviction of the tenants from all the four buildings.

facts.text: Both parties filed revision to District Judge under s. 20 of Kerala Act 2 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Both parties went in revision to the District Judge, Kottayam under s. 20 of Kerala Act 2 of 1965.

facts.text: Kerala High Court dismissed tenant's revision under s. 115 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The tenant went up to the Kerala High Court by way of revision under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure and the High Court found that numbergrounds had been made out for interference with the order of the District Judge and as such dismissed the petition with companyts.

facts.text: Buildings were let out as a lodging house.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, Mr. Daphtary argued that on the facts the companyrts be- low should number have companye to the companyclusion that there was a subletting within the mischief of the Act. The buildings were let out as a lodging house and the evidence showed that one of the rooms was in the occupation of a lawyer who had been there for years and had put up his name board outside the room.

facts.text: One room occupied by a lawyer for years, with name board outside.

anchor.surface_text: and the evidence showed that one of the rooms was in the occupation of a lawyer who had been there for years and had put up his name board outside the room. Besides the name board of the lawyer, there were the name boards of other persons and the lawyer paid rent on a daily basis.

facts.text: Lawyer paid rent on daily basis and installed telephone in room.

anchor.surface_text: Besides the name board of the lawyer, there were the name boards of other persons and the lawyer paid rent on a daily basis. The lawyer had installed a telephone in his room.

facts.text: District Court and High Court accepted evidence as conclusive of sub-letting.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there was sufficient evidence to hold that the lawyer was in exclusive possession of the room and although the rent was paid on a daily basis it was number a case of the grant of a licence. In any event, the finding as to sub-letting does number call for interference in this case seeing that the District Court and the High Court both accepted the evidence as companyclusive of sub-letting.

facts.text: Kerala Act of 1959 repealed by Kerala Buildings Lease and Rent Control Act, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: It is pertinent to numbere here that the Kerala Act of 1959 was repealed by the Kerala Buildings  Lease and Rent Control  Act, 1965 and the new Act came into force on 1st April, 1965.

facts.text: Sub-letting occurred before commencement of 1965 Act.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel urged that whatever may have been the provision under the Act of 1959 the proceedings by the landlord having been started after the repeal of that Act and the companymencement of the Act of 1965 the landlord companyld get possession of the premises only if he satisfied the tests laid down in sub-s.  4  which did number make subletting before the companymencement of the Act a ground for eviction.

facts.text: Two buildings subject to separate and independent agreements.

anchor.surface_text: He however found that two of the buildings formed the subject matter of separate and independent agreements between the parties and as such allowed eviction of the tenants from two only out of the four properties.

facts.text: Supreme Court found sufficient evidence for sub-letting by tenant.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there was sufficient evidence to hold that the lawyer was in exclusive possession of the room and although the rent was paid on a daily basis it was number a case of the grant of a licence.

issues.text: Whether, assuming there was sub-letting by the tenant, a proceeding for eviction would lie only under the provisions of the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act, 1965, requiring the sub-letting to be after its commencement

anchor.surface_text: The main point urged by Mr. Daphtary counsel for the appel- lant was that assuming that there was a sub-letting by the tenant a proceeding for eviction would only lie under the provisions of the Act of 1965. Omitting the provisos, s. 11(1) of the Act provided that Notwithstanding anything to the companytrary companytained

issues.text: Whether sub-s. (4)(i) of s. 11 of the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act, 1959 contained a corresponding provision to s. 11(4) of the 1965 Act within the meaning of the proviso to s. 34(1) of the 1965 Act

anchor.surface_text: Sub-s. (4)(i) of s. 11 however gave the landlord a right to apply for eviction land for an order directing him to be put in possession of the building if the tenant has without the companysent of the landlord transferred his right under the lease or sub-let the entire building or any portion thereof, if the lease does number companyfer on him any right to do so, or the landlord has number companysented to such sub-letting We find ourselves unable to accept Mr. Daphtarys argument that the above quoted provision of s. 11 of the Act of 1959 was number a companyresponding provision within the meaning of the proviso to sub-s. (1) of s. 34 of the Act of 1965.

issues.text: Whether the non-obstante clause in s. 11(1) of the 1965 Act excludes the operation of the savings provision in s. 34(1) of the same Act and the 1959 Act

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Daphtary raised a further companytention that under the express words of sub-s. (1) of s. 11 of the Act of 1965 the operation of any other law including the Act of 1959 was excluded. We do number think that is the proper companystruction to be put on the words of sub-s. (1) of s. 11 in view of s. 34(1) of the same Act.

issues.text: Whether s. 4 of the Kerala Interpretation and General Clauses Act, 1125 applied or a different intention appeared from s. 34(1) of the 1965 Act

anchor.surface_text: Reference in this companynection may also be made to s. 4 of the Kerala Interpretation and General Clauses Act, 1125 (Act 7 of 1125) Where any Act repeals any enactment hitherto made or hereafter to be made, then, unless a different intention appears, the repeal shall number- (a) revive anything number in force or existing at the time at which the repeal takes effect or (b) affect the previous operation of any enactment so repealed or anything duly done or suffered thereunder or (c) affect any right, privilege, obligation or liability acquired, accrued or incurred under any enactment so repealed or It was argued by Mr. Daphtary that s. 4 was number applicable because a different intention appeared from s. 34(1) of the Act of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, Mr. Daphtary argued that on the facts the companyrts be- low should number have companye to the companyclusion that there was a subletting within the mischief of the Act. The buildings were let out as a lodging house and the evidence showed that one of the rooms was in the occupation of a lawyer who had been there for years and had put up his name board outside the room. Besides the name board of the lawyer, there were the name boards of other persons and the lawyer paid rent on a daily basis. The lawyer had installed a telephone in his room. In our opinion, there was sufficient evidence to hold that the lawyer was in exclusive possession of the room and although the rent was paid on a daily basis it was number a case of the grant of a licence.

holdings.text: A legal proceeding which could have been instituted, continued or enforced under the repealed Act of 1959 may be instituted under the corresponding provisions of the 1965 Act per s.34(1) proviso, allowing eviction for pre-commencement sub-letting.

anchor.surface_text: It is to be noted however that s. 34 of the Act of 1965 provided for savings and special provision in the following manner. Sub- s. (1) thereof runs as follows Notwithstanding the expiry of the Kerala Buildings Lease and Rent Control Act, 1959 (Kerala Act 16 of 1959) hereinafter in this section referred

holdings.reasoning_summary: Savings clause in s.34(1) 1965 Act preserves proceedings under repealed 1959 Act via corresponding provisions; s.4 Interpretation Act supports unless different intention, which does not appear.

holdings.text: s.11(4)(i) of 1959 Act is a corresponding provision to s.11(4) of 1965 Act within meaning of s.34(1) proviso.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-s. (4)(i) of s. 11 however gave the landlord a right to apply for eviction land for an order directing him to be put in possession of the building if the tenant has without the consent of the landlord transferred his right under the lease or sub-let the entire building or any portion thereof, if the lease does not confer on him any right to do so, or the landlord has not consented to such sub-letting We find ourselves unable to accept Mr. Daphtarys argument that the above quoted provision of s. 11 of the Act of 1959 was not a corresponding provision within the meaning of the proviso to sub-s. (1) of s. 34 of the Act of 1965.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Corresponding' means in harmony with, similar or analogous to, not identical; provisions substantially match on sub-letting ground for eviction.

holdings.text: Non-obstante clause in s.11(1) of 1965 Act does not exclude operation of s.34(1) savings provision of same Act.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Daphtary raised a further contention that under the express words of sub-s. (1) of s. 11 of the Act of 1965 the operation of any other law including the Act of 1959 was excluded. We do not think that is the proper construction to be put on the words of sub-s. (1) of s. 11 in view of s. 34(1) of the same Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proper construction harmonises s.11(1) with s.34(1) of same Act; non-obstante does not override internal savings clause.

holdings.text: s.4 of Kerala Interpretation and General Clauses Act applies as no different intention appears from s.34(1) of 1965 Act.

anchor.surface_text: Reference in this connection may also be made to s. 4 of the Kerala Interpretation and General Clauses Act, 1125 (Act 7 of 1125) Where any Act repeals any enactment hitherto made or hereafter to be made, then, unless a different intention appears, the repeal shall not- (a) revive anything not in force or existing at the time at which the repeal takes effect or (b) affect the previous operation of any enactment so repealed or anything duly done or suffered thereunder or (c) affect any right, privilege, obligation or liability acquired, accrued or incurred under any enactment so repealed or It was argued by Mr. Daphtary that s. 4 was not applicable because a different intention appeared from s. 34(1) of the Act of 1965. We find ourselves unable to accept this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects argument of different intention; s.34(1) proviso aligns with and reinforces general repeal effects under s.4.

holdings.text: District Court under s.20(1) of 1965 Act empowered to revise Subordinate Judge's finding on sub-letting, as power wider than s.115 CPC, extends to legality, regularity or propriety.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.20(1) explicitly allows satisfaction on legality, regularity or propriety, not limited to jurisdiction like s.115 CPC.

holdings.text: There was sub-letting as lawyer in exclusive possession of room (name board, telephone, daily rent not decisive of licence).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence (long occupation, name board, telephone) shows exclusive possession constituting sub-letting, not licence; lower courts' concurrent findings not to be interfered with.

(4)(i) of s. 11 however gave the landlord a right to apply for eviction land for an order directing him to be put in possession of the building if the tenant has without the consent of the landlord transferred his right under the lease or sub-let the entire building or any portion thereof, if the lease does not confer on him any right to do so, or the landlord has not consented to such sub-letting We find ourselves unable to accept Mr. Daphtarys argument that the above quoted provision of s. 11 of the Act of 1959 was not a corresponding provision within the meaning of the proviso to sub-s. (1) of s. 34 of the Act of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Daphtary raised a further contention that under the express words of sub-s. (1) of s. 11 of the Act of 1965 the operation of any other law including the Act of 1959 was excluded. We do not think that is the proper construction to be put on the words of sub-s. (1) of s. 11 in view of s. 34(1) of the same Act.

In any event, the finding as to sub-letting does number call for interference in this case seeing that the District Court and the High Court both accepted the evidence as companyclusive of sub-letting.

anchor.surface_text: Reference in this connection may also be made to s. 4 of the Kerala Interpretation and General Clauses Act, 1125 (Act 7 of 1125) Where any Act repeals any enactment hitherto made or hereafter to be made, then, unless a different intention appears, the repeal shall not- (a) revive anything not in force or existing at the time at which the repeal takes effect or (b) affect the previous operation of any enactment so repealed or anything duly done or suffered thereunder or (c) affect any right, privilege, obligation or liability acquired, accrued or incurred under any enactment so repealed or It was argued by Mr. Daphtary that s. 4 was not applicable because a different intention appeared from s. 34(1) of the Act of 1965. We find ourselves unable to accept this contention.

In any event, the finding as to sub-letting does number call for interference in this case seeing that the District Court and the High Court both accepted the evidence as companyclusive of sub-letting.
